history.content:
The linked post below is with regards to GSIs, which is a separate issue. Mainly because classes can have infinite if the instructor were both willing to accommodate the logistics and can hire enough GSIs. Keep in mind that the job of professors is primarily to do research, not teach classes. There's an argument to be made that maybe to be more cost effective, we should keep a larger pool of non-tenure track lecturers, much like stats and math do. But that seems to be against the philosophy of the department, for reasons I don't know.

At the research level (this is what most program rankings are based on), Berkeley EECS is very good and will continue to be. I see no evidence of declining research quality. In fact, maybe this is an argument to start cutting undergraduate enrollment in the CS major, because the more professors get bogged down in managing classes, the less time they have to do research. Intro classes like CS 61A (which don't really benefit from being taught by specialized researchers anyways) would incredibly taxing for a research faculty to teach, not even considering that this would be a tremendous waste of time that could have been spent doing other things that add to the research credibility of the school.

Just because SWE has boomed as a job for fresh undergrads to go into doesn't mean that there is more money to do research in CS. The university has to budget hiring faculty in different departments, and because faculty are usually hired for tenure-track, there is the expectation that the budget is able to support the professor's pay for the next 40 or so years, which is obviously very expensive. Say EECS hired a specialist in blockchain or deep RL, but the topic goes out of fashion. EECS is still on the hook for paying the professor's salary for the next couple of decades. That professor is likely too specialized to easily jump into the new hot thing, so it would be terrible investment.

Hiring tenured faculty is a very very difficult and time-consuming process, simply because the prospective professor has a long process of being vetted (there's tens of millions of dollars at stake). Also keep in mind that although undergrad tuition does pay professor salaries, professors need a team of graduate students to maintain productive research. Graduate students are paid for by grants from the federal government or private companies, which won't ramp up grant money simply because SWE is more popular now than it used to be. So we would also need to hire a lot more grad students, but without more funds to pay for them. Doing so would be catastrophic.

children.subject: For which class do you notice a faculty shortage?
Thanks for the link. The post you linked to refers to TAs mostly. I was curious about actual lecturers and professors as well.

Depends who you ask. EECS has the largest student/faculty ratio of any department on campus, and by some official measures we're supposed to have a lot more faculty, based on our number of students. On the other hand, the university adds only a limited number of new professors each year, and EECS can't have all the faculty slots. There's also resistance from departments on campus who see us as a behemoth potentially unbalancing the university. So we haven't been getting enough hiring slots to match the growth in students. (Especially when you take into account the explosion in Data Science, for which we've masochistically taken responsibility for a big portion of the curriculum. Gotta admire my colleagues for taking on so much responsibility/punishment with such aplomb/obliviousness.)

We certainly don't have "trouble hiring", though. Just this past year, we hired at least five new profs of amazing quality.

history.content: Is there a faculty shortage in the CS department? It seems like the department is having trouble hiring and that some classes aren’t expanding even when it is really needed. I am worried about the future of the CS program here. Anyone have any idea on what the issue is and what is being done to mitigate it?
